author: rkeithhill
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------
Start Ubuntu 16.04 running in WSL.
Start pwsh-preview (preview 3)
Create another account (sudo adduser test (password: test)
Execute `su - test` to log in and verify password.  Exit that login.

Execute:

```powershell
Start-Job -Credential (Get-Credential) {whoami} | Wait-Job | Receive-Job
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

Outputs
```none
test
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
An error has occurred which PowerShell cannot handle. A remote session might have ended.
+ CategoryInfo          : OpenError: (localhost:String) [], PSRemotingDataStructureException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : PSSessionStateBroken
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.1.0-preview.3
OS                             Linux 4.4.0-17134-Microsoft #112-Microsoft Thu Jun 07 22:57:00 PST 2018
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
I see this issue was referenced in #1365 and was closed as fixed.  Perhaps a regression?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
For the sake of completeness, I should also mention that _Windows PowerShell_ breaks in yet another way:

```none
[localhost] An error occurred while starting the background process. Error reported: The directory name is invalid.
```

In Windows PowerShell, `Start-Job` uses a _fixed_ working directory for background jobs, namely the calling user's `Documents` folder, so I _presume_ the problem is that  the (by definition non-elevated) target user process isn't permitted to access this directory.

That said, if you run the `Start-Job -Credential` command from an _elevated_ session in WinPS, it does succeed (and does use the _target_ user's `Documents` folder) - but this requirement is neither documented nor should it be necessary, given that `runas.exe` can run as a different user just fine even from non-elevated sessions.

Conversely, running `Start-Job -Credential` _in PS Core_ with elevation also breaks as described.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
A workaround for _Windows PowerShell_ (doesn't help in PS Core): 

As someone [figured out on Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/q/68757644/45375), the problem can be worked around by setting the _process-level_ working directory to one the target user is permitted to access:

```powershell
# Works.
[environment]::CurrentDirectory = 'C:\'; Start-Job -Credential (Get-Credential otheruser) { whoami } | Receive-Job -Wait -AutoRemoveJob
```
